challenge.title: Step 19
challenge.description:
Add one last node, 'D', which is connected with 'A' and 'C'.

Modify your dictionary to represent this structure. Again, use a list to represent multiple connections.

tests.text: Your dictionary should have 4 keys called 'A', 'B', 'C', and 'D'.
tests.testString:
({ test: () => assert(runPython(`
    key_list = ["A", "B", "C", "D"]
    len(my_graph) == 4 and all(key in my_graph for key in key_list)
  `))
})

tests.text: my_graph['A'] should be a list containing 'B' and 'D'.
tests.testString:
({ test: () => assert(runPython(`
    len(my_graph["A"]) == 2 and "B" in my_graph["A"] and "D" in my_graph["A"]
  `))
})

tests.text: my_graph['B'] should be a list containing 'A' and 'C'.
tests.testString:
({ test: () => assert(runPython(`
    len(my_graph["B"]) == 2 and "A" in my_graph["B"] and "C" in my_graph["B"]
  `))
})

tests.text: my_graph['C'] should be a list containing 'B' and 'D'.
tests.testString:
({ test: () => assert(runPython(`
    len(my_graph["C"]) == 2 and "B" in my_graph["C"] and "D" in my_graph["C"]
  `))
})

tests.text: my_graph['D'] should be a list containing 'A' and 'C'.
tests.testString:
({ test: () => assert(runPython(`
    len(my_graph["D"]) == 2 and "A" in my_graph["D"] and "C" in my_graph["D"]
  `))
})

challengeFiles.name: main
